quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
def a(b)
  puts b/2
end
a(9)
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Parameters[/h1]

A method declaration can include [b]parameters[/b], which you define inside parentheses after the method name.
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="rb" codeId="1042"]def sqr[b](x)[/b]
  puts x*x
end

sqr[b](8) [/b]
# outputs 64[/code]
The defined [b]sqr [/b]method has one parameter (called [b]x[/b]) and outputs its square. You can name your parameters anything you like.
When calling the method, we "pass" the actual parameter value to the method using parentheses. 
[note]The actual parameter value is called an [b]argument[/b]. 
So, in the above example, x is the [b]parameter [/b]of the method, while 8 is the [b]argument[/b].[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to declare a method taking two parameters and outputting their product (multiplication).
[!raw!]
{0} mult(x, y)
  puts x*{1}
end
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Multiple Parameters[/h1]

A method can include multiple parameters, separated by [b]commas[/b].
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="rb" codeId="1043"]def sum[b](a, b)[/b]
  puts a+b
end

sum(7, 4) 
# outputs 11

sum(88, 164)
# outputs 252[/code]
You can also pass variable arguments: [code format="rb" codeId="1044"]def sum(a, b, c)
  puts a+b+c
end

x = 2
y = 42
z = 6
sum(x, y, z)
# outputs 50[/code]
